What is the term for a dramatic stage work for only one character*monodrama
What is a term describing the course of a melody or melodies*motion
What is a term for music which recurs and develops in the form of a quotation*motto theme
What is a term describing (from the 1960's) dramatic works simpler than opera and suitable for the concert platform*music theatre
What term refers to an instruction to a singer or instrumentalist to perform in the normal way*naturale
What term refers to a chord on the fourth degree of the scale with a minor third and sixth (e.g. in C major it includes the notes F, A flat and D flat)*Neapolitan sixth
What term describes a trend, especially in the 1920's, characterised by its use of the concerto grosso technique, contrapuntal writing and avoidance of emotion*neo-classical
Which term refers to a note which is not part of the chord with which it sounds*non-harmonic note
Which term refers to the performance of a group of adjacent notes simultaneously on the piano*note cluster
What term describes the movement of parts or melodies when one remains on the same note and the other moves in some direction*oblique motion
What is the interval of eight steps (e.g. C to C on the white notes of the piano)*octave
What is a composition for eight voices or instruments, or simply eight people*octet
What is a drama in which all or most characters sing and in which music is an important element*opera
What is a stage work involving elements of both opera and oratorio*opera oratorio
What is a term applied in the l9th century to lighter styles of opera involving dialogue, this style is sometimes referred to as light opera*operetta
What is a musical composition consisting of an extended setting of a religious or epic text for chorus, soloists and orchestra for performance in a church or concert hall*oratorio
What is a medieval type of part-writing based on plainsong and harmonised by either one, two or three parallel parts*organum
What is the (It.) musical term for an octave, often written 8ve*ottava
Any notes of the harmonic series are given which name except for the first fundamental*overtone
What was traditionally a play in mime but nowadays it is a Christmas stage entertainment based on a fairy tale or other traditional source with dialogue, popular songs, costumes and actions*pantomime
What is the movement of two or more parts in the same direction while also keeping the same interval between them*parallel motion
What is the music of a particular voice or instrument in an ensemble*part
What is the (It.) musical term for voice-part*parte
What is the (It.) musical term for a suite*partita
What is the composing of polyphonic music and the writing of equally good melodic parts*part-writing
What is a section of a composition, usually with no structural importance*passage
What is a note not belonging to the harmony but interposed to secure a smooth transition*passing note
What is an artistic work in a style that imitates that of another work, artist, or period*pastiche
What is an alternative name for the madrigal, or any piece representing country life*pastoral
Popular in opera, what is a comic song in which words, sung as fast as possible, are often tongue-twisters*patter song
What is the (It.) musical term for a rest (not a pause)*pausa
In music, what is a wait of indefinite length on a note or rest*pause
What is a slow, stately dance usually in duple time dating from the 16th century*pavan
What is the fundamental or lowest note of the harmonic series especially applied to the playing of brass instruments*pedal
What is a note, usually in the bass, which is held below changing harmonies above, with which it may be discordant*pedal point
What is a five note scale, the commonest being without minor seconds (e.g. CDEGA-C...)*pentatonic
What is the (It.) musical term for by, through, for*per
What is a cadence in which the chord of the dominant immediately precedes that of the tonic*perfect cadence
What are the intervals of the octave, fourth and fifth*perfect intervals
What is a sense of pitch which enables a person to identify a note simply by hearing it*perfect pitch
In medieval music, what was triple time*perfect time
What is the (Lat.) musical term for a fast piece of music in which a rapid repetitive note-pattern is played throughout*perpetuum mobile
What is the (It.) musical term for heavy, ponderous*pesante
What is the (Ger.) musical term for fantasy*phantasie
What is a group of notes forming a unit of a melody*phrase
What is a cadence which ends on the dominant of the relative minor*phrygian cadence
What is the mode which, on the white keys of the piano, is represented by E to E*phrygian mode
What is the (It.) musical term for pleasantly*piacevole
What is the (It.) musical term for plaintively*piangendo
What is the (It.) musical term for very soft*pianissimo
What is the standard abbreviation in French and English for pianoforte*piano
What is the (It.) musical term for soft and loud*pianoforte
What is the (It.) musical term for somewhat, rather*piuttosto
What is the abbreviation of pizzicato*pizz
What is the (It.) musical term for the indication to pluck notes on a bowed string instrument*pizzicato
What is the (Gk.) musical term for a type of florid passage in plainsong sung to a single vowel*pneuma
What is the (It.) musical term for slightly, little, rather*poco
What is a lively dance of Bohemian origin in duple time*polka
What is a slow dance of Polish origin in triple time, consisting chiefly of an intricate march or procession*polonaise
Which musical term describes the use of several choirs performing both separately and jointly in a composition*polychoral
What is the style of simultaneously combining a number of parts, each forming an individual melody and harmonizing with each othe*polyphony
What is a rhythm which makes use of two or more different rhythms simultaneously*polyrhythm
What is the simultaneous use of two or more keys in a musical composition*polytonality
What is the (It.) musical term for in a pompous manner*pomposo
What is a slide from one note to another, especially in singing or playing the violin*portamento
What is the musical term for a final piece of a composition*postlude
What is the (Fr.) musical term for up bow as opposed to tire, down bow*pousse
What is the abbreviation for pianissimo, very soft*pp
What is the (It.) musical term for precise*preciso
Which musical term describes music before Haydn and Mozart and also (more vaguely) describing music before Bach*pre-classical
What is an introductory piece or movement before a fugue, an act of an opera*prelude
What is the (It.) musical term for fast, in Mozart's music this means as fast as possible*presto
What is the (It.) musical term for a female singer with the most important part in an opera*prima donna
What is the (It.) musical term for first*primo
What music interprets or describes a story, painting, poem, landscape or emotional experience. Opposite of absolute music*programme music
What is the movement from one note or chord to another in music*progression
What is the systematic plan of beginning in one key and ending in another in a movement*progressive tonality
What is a counterpoint in which four melodies can exchange position*quadruple counterpoint
What is a fugue with four different subjects*quadruple fugue
What is a chord of four notes played on a bowed string instrument*quadruple stop
What is a group of four notes to be played in the time of 3*quadruplet
In 4/4 time, what is the equivalent of one beat*quarter note*crotchet
What is the musical term for a composition for four performers*quartet
What is the (It.) musical term for as if, almost*quasi
What is a dance similar to a fast foxtrot*quickstep
What is the musical term for a composition for five performers*quintet
What is the musical term for a group of five notes to be performed in the time of 4*quintuplet
What is the musical term for time with five beats, usually quarter notes, to the bar (e.g. 5/4 time)*quintuple time
What is the musical abbreviation of both ray in the tonic sol-fa and respond*r
What is the (It.) musical term for rage*rabbia
What is the (It.) musical term for doubling, usually indicates doubling of the bass at an octave below*raddoppiamento
What is the musical abbreviation of rallentando*rall
What is the (Ger.) musical term for quick*rasch
Which is a part of a movement (especially one in sonata form) in which themes from the exposition are restated*recapitulation
Which musical term is an abbreviation of recitative*recit
What is a performance of a programme of music by a soloist or small group*recital
Which musical term is a style of singing used in opera and oratorio for dialogue and some narrative which is more closely related to dramatic speech in pitch and rhythm than to song*recitative
In a fugue, which term describes an extra voice in the initial entries or exposition*redundant entry
What is a lively Scottish or Irish folk dance*reel
Which musical term means a recurring section of a song (both words and music) at the end of each stanza*refrain
Which musical term means the division of compass of a singer's voice or a set of organ pipes controlled by one particular stop*register
Which musical term (Fr.) means that the title is sometimes found in spirited movements in suites of the baroque period*rejouissance
Which musical term refers to each key signature being shared by two keys*relative
Which musical term means(Fr.) the repeating of a passage or note*repetition
Which musical term means to repeat (It)*replica
Which musical term can mean a repeated passage in music*reprise
Which musical term means in harmony this is the progression from a discord to a concord*resolution
Which musical term means a plainsong chant sung by a chorus alternating with solo verse*respond*responsory
Which musical term means a silence in a performer's part indicated by symbols corresponding to certain beats*rest
What is the musical abbreviation for rinforzando*rf*rfz
What is the musical abbreviation for right hand*rh
What is a free instrumental composition in one extended movement, typically one that is emotional in character*rhapsody

In music, what is the sixth degree of a major or minor scale*sub-mediant
In music, what is the second degree of the major or minor scale*supertonic
In music, what is the use of a non-harmonic tone to delay the resolution of a chord*suspension
What is the name of the right pedal on the piano which raises the felt dampers allowing the strings to vibrate freely*sustaining pedal
Which musical term means quick; light*svelto
In music, what is a piece for large orchestra, usually in four movements, in which the first movement often is in sonata form*symphony
In music, what is an accent on an unexpected beat*syncopation
In music, an indication that a performer or instrument has no part in a particular movement or section*tacet
Which musical term means so much*tanto
What is a very fast Italian dance with alternating major and minor key sections in 6/8 time*tarantella
Which musical term (It.) means slow*tardo
Which musical term (It.) means theme*tema
In music what is the rate of speed in a musical work*tempo
Which musical term means return to the original tempo*tempo primo
Which musical term (It.) means sustaining*tenendo
Which musical term (It.) means tenderly*teneramente
Which musical term (It.) means to hold or sustain a note longer than the indicated value*tenuto
In music, what is a three-part form in which the middle section is different from the other sections*ternary form
In music, what is a term used to describe music based on chords arranged in intervals of thirds*tertian harmony
In music, what is the general pitch range of a vocal part*tessitura
In music, what is the term used to describe the way in which melodic lines are combined, either with or without accompaniment*texture
In music, what is a term used to describe a song in which the music for each stanza is different*through-composed
Which musical term means a melodic group of notes forming the basis or chief idea in a composition by repetition or development*theme
In music, in solmization, the seventh degree of the major scale*ti
In music, what is a line joining two adjacent notes of the same pitch together, indicating that the first note only should be played but should be prolonged until the second note's time value is up*tie
Which musical term describes the basic rhythmical patterns in music*time
Which musical term means generally a solo instrumental piece involving rapid changes of notes to demonstrate the player's touch*toccata
In music, the term used to describe the organization of the melodic and harmonic elements to give a feeling of a key center or a tonic pitch*tonality
Which musical term (Sp.) means tune or air*tonada
Which musical term means the interval consisting of two semitones or the quality of sound of an instrument*tone
Which musical term means the first degree of the scale or a triad built on that degree*tonic
In music, what are the simultaneous sounding of two or more adjacent tones*tone clusters
In music, on wind instruments, what is is articulation with the tongue*tonguing
Which musical term (It.) means quick or rapid*tosto
Which musical term (It.) means calm*tranquillo
Which musical term means a subordinate passage serving as a link to another more important one or a sudden change of key not going through the normal procedures referred to as modulation*transition
Which musical term means the writing down or performing of music in a different key from the original*transposition
Which musical term (Ger.) means sad*traurig
Which musical term (It.) indicates to pianists that the left (soft) pedal is to be released*tre corde
Which musical term (Fr.) means trill*tremblement
Which musical term (It.) means employing tremolo*tremolando
Which musical term (It.) means the rapid reiteration of a single note*tremolo
Which musical term means an organ device producing a vibrato effect by alternately increasing and decreasing the wind pressure*tremulant
Which musical term means a lively Cossack dance in 2/4 time*trepak
In music, what is a chord of three tones arranged in thirds*triad
Which musical term means a musical ornament consisting of rapid alternation starting with the written note and then the note above*trill
Which musical term (Ger.) means a drinking song*trinklied
Which musical term means a vocal or instrumental piece for three performers*trio
Which musical term means a composition usually for two violins and a 'cello, with a keyboard playing the bass line and supporting harmonies*trio sonata
Which musical term means a concerto for three solo instruments with orchestra*triple concerto
In music, what is a meter based on three beats, or a multiple of three, in a measure*triple meter
Which musical term means the invertible counterpoint in which three parts can be interchanged, each making a suitable bass for the other*triple counterpoint
Which musical term means the playing of three notes simultaneously on a stringed instrument by the placing of the left hand fingers on the strings and shortening the vibrating length*triple stop
Which musical term means a group of three notes played in the time of two*triplet
Which musical term means time consisting of three beats to the bar*triple time
Which musical term means the rapid articulation of T-K-T on a wind instrument*triple tonguing
Which musical term means the interval of three tones (e.g. F to B)*tritone
Which musical term (It.) means a note broken off abruptly especially in vocal music*tronco
Which musical term (It.) means too much*troppo
Which musical term means to set the temperament of an instrument*tuning
Which musical term (It.) indicates to pianists to release the left-hand pedal*tutte le corde
Which musical term (It.) generally means all the players*tutti
Which musical term (Ger.) means over, above*uber
Which musical term (Ger.) means exercise*ubung
Which musical term (Ger.) means inversion, reversal*umkehrung
Which musical term (It.) means humour*umore
Which musical term (It.) indicates to pianists to use the left (soft) pedal to reduce the volume*una corda
Which musical term means the sound of two or more voices singing simultaneously at the same pitch*unison
Which musical term means the upward movement of a conductor's hand or baton, especially indicating the beat before the main accent in a bar of music*upbeat
What is the musical term for a bow stroke on stringed instruments from point to heel*up-bow
Which musical term generally means to improvise a song accompaniment*vamp
Which musical term means the modification or development of a theme, passage or figure with the theme always remaining recognizable*variation
Which musical term (Ger.) gives indication to pianists to use the soft (left) pedal*verschiebung
Which musical term means a rapid but minute fluctuation in pitch to give an expressive quality to a note*vibrato
What is the musical term for a performer with brilliant technique and exceptional skill*virtuoso
Which Italian musical term means lively*vivace
Which Italian musical term means voice*voce
Which Italian musical term means fast and light*volante
Which Italian musical term means turn over (the page) quickly*Volti subito
Which musical term means generally a free style keyboard piece; or an organ solo played before and after an Anglican service*voluntary
